body:
Well, this patch is just a very first step. I'm planning to add some others down on the road, I just would like it to be visible from the start, to be able to talk this through as a process not just one big change.
@JaroslavTulach Unfortunately my direction is not that far reaching. Having general project with natures seems to be a compelling idea, though that would be a big step to jump. I'm not sure if I can make that jump happen. Though if anyone could deliver that, I would happily ditch this set of patches in favor of that. So I'm not trying to reaching that high.
So my plan is to try something built on the current ProjectFactory2 and ProjectManager.Result. My steps would be:
1. Enhance the PM API to be able to query/load Project "natures" recongnized by the IDE.
1. Improve the isProject2 usage to actually return project type
1. Add an Open Project As action if more than one project "nature" is detected on a folder.
1. Fix: There could be some glitches around re-opening the projects.
1. Probably add more UI entry for the project "nature" selection

I have something half working on 3., but need to do some real work on 2.
@geertjanw @JaroslavTulach shall we move this further. It is pretty easy to revert in case we need that. I'd like to see this in the Thursday's netbeans-dev snap drop.
I suggest we create a branch for l10n then merging this PR into it once. Some people can work on this per language. If OK, I'll create a new branch (e.g. `3rd-donation-l10n`).

Hi @vieiro @sdedic @JaroslavTulach, @geertjanw ,@neilcsmith-net 
As I can use the netbeans-vm, I created a live demo here, http://bits.netbeans.org/apidoctest/
I would appreciate review for the website, to see if this is usable, (not loosing info from previous apidoc system)
I try to unframe (because if we switch to jdk12 in the future frame are no more present) , add search.
 
As json contains all the Apache NetBeans Version it's easy to create a navbar to locate the current version of apidoc in the versions timeline. The data are taken from my local master branch, but I force a build using release90 data of the json to see if it works. (apichanges are not 9.0, but release date should match)
I remove the old oracle javadoc because we may have 404 issue and put a link to the bits.netbeans.org where I will later put the list here. (at least the last 8.2)

This build system will work on anybranch and we never have to care on apidoc date, apidoc stability.
This may ease a bit the release management, but I have no idea on how to take care of the BUNDLE file pointed in #1304 by @neilcsmith-net

Interesting!  Need to find some time to look more.

> This may ease a bit the release management, but I have no idea on how to take care of the BUNDLE file pointed in #1304 by @neilcsmith-net

With regard to this, I had some thoughts on templating via the build to have it all in one place.  We need version (for userdir, update centres, etc.) and optional version suffix (eg. -beta1) for use in display areas (eg. window, About).  Potentially that can be taken from the same place you're setting it?

The [demo](http://bits.netbeans.org/apidoctest/) is quite slick. I admire your courage to dig deep into all the `.xsl` transformations I have once written (I prefer to stay away). Looks like the integration with `arch.xml`, `apichanges.xml` and `@codesnippet` doclet still works (that makes me happy). Good job.

What is the sense of integrating it into the main repository if we're
building individual extensions per language?
Another option could be to create a new repository that holds the extension
plus the donated sources. It could be added as a git "submodule" to the
main repository (if needed).
Boris

What I'm wondering is, why does this pull request pass the CI test if it's disapproved of by the rat job because of missing licenses?

@JaroslavTulach xsl were clear.

@neilcsmith-net data can be seen here: 
https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=netbeans-jenkins-lib.git;a=blob;f=meta/netbeansrelease.json
Build is done according to branch.
(json is missing the extra term version like feature update 1 and LTS terms at least for website and but can be envisioned for about and welcome)

Rereading 10times but still complex sorry :p :
Assuming we  may produce the version json is set with/
0) json updated with data
1) releaseAAA branch is created on git, .
   We add an optional version -beta1 on releaseAAA with LTS as extra version term. 
   It will generate a releaseAAA-LTS-beta1 with everything in about,welcome....  
   But as beta1 is set in source+installers, once RM take and sign for a vote, it would be a vote for releaseAAALTS-beta1 isn't? 
   We have to wait until we set option-version to empty string to vote on releaseAAA-LST, assuming we consider out of beta.

-- Aside that, on the voting candidate if we want to releaseAAALTS we can put it on a distinctive folder and not renaming per Vote the sources zip
dist/dev/netbeans/AAA-VC1/releaseAAALTS-sources.zip

---
For the production, 
For apidoc (assuming we merge the pr)  the version read from json will be set in temp build files, easy move no source modification. 
For NetBeans bundle file,ant will modify a Bundle file on source repo, git will say uncommited change. We need a gentle way to do this modification.
(No sure a good idea, alter the build of concerned module to preprocess bundle file before compilation).

@ebarboni thanks!  Wondering whether some of this might be easier on email than here - maybe separate addition to this PR anyway?  But ...

> data can be seen here:
https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=netbeans-jenkins-lib.git;a=blob;f=meta/netbeansrelease.json

On build / bundle parameters I think we need to find a way to put that info in the NetBeans sources?  It should be possible to build from source and get the right artefacts.  That might apply to other things in that JSON too?

> Aside that, on the voting candidate if we want to releaseAAALTS we can put it on a distinctive folder and not renaming per Vote the sources zip

Voting candidates need to be manually signed and renamed at present - that doesn't seem much of an issue.  File renaming is the easy part.  Ideally all the betas for NB 11.1 would have been labelled in the UI.

> For NetBeans bundle file,ant will modify a Bundle file on source repo, git will say uncommited change. We need a gentle way to do this modification.
(No sure a good idea, alter the build of concerned module to preprocess bundle file before compilation).

Why?  Doing find and replace on the file as it's copied across in the build seems the right approach here?  It involves adding a few lines to the build scripts of a couple of modules inside `/nb`.

@neilcsmith-net:

ReleaseJsonProperties ant do the job of getting json info for a branch (default master) apidoc 'can be generalised to get more infos'. It transform json into ant properties + xml file. if no json available during build it's a bit like not having a dependencies. (Break build).
The current netbeans-TLP has to download json itself because it's old build.

a bit of rationale :
We would like to have no "branding" commit on branch cut.
With @vieiro we would like to use the json info for our INFRA, building the apidoc folder, the netbeans website meta dl page. Should not only be in the netbeans source because on every release we would have to recommit the new information on all previous branches. 
I personaly want the apidoc to know the "future version" at anytime. If user bookmark 9.0 version it will then show that there are more recent version.

To sum up:
the workflow would be like that
RELEASEA-betan with betan branding (no vote)
then once acceptance ok
RELEASEA no more beta branding but artifacts rename -vcn (voting cantidate)
(more or less like we have now except the branding)

Your right mail would be better.

> We would like to have no "branding" commit on branch cut.

+1 to reducing the amount of branding changes required on the release branch (or master tag).  But -1 from me to not having _any_ version  / branding commits in the source tree.  IMO someone should be able to checkout the sources at any particular tag / commit and build the "correct" version of the IDE.  And that build shouldn't change over time.

What you're aiming at I agree with, just wary of moving further away from reproducible builds than towards it. :smile:

> What is the sense of integrating it into the main repository if we're
building individual extensions per language?

I meant that we should create PRs to change the license headers per language because this integration is so huge. It's hard work to do it only one person and it takes much time :)
Also see @JaroslavTulach 's comment.

Thanks.

Is the goal implementing an alternative to JDT-LS ?
Is it described somewhere why an alternative to JDT-LS is desired in first place and what would be the differentiators between this and JDT-LS? (cc @fbricon)

I think, we are not good yet for reproducible build, buildnumber is an issue, jdk version, ant version, maven version should be taken into account.
jar ordering, jar building, (removing timestamp) much more :D

Have maybe a different plan but may statisfy better.

trying an example:
```
git branch master with hash 000
git branch releaseA with following hash;
git hash 123 for beta1 -- this is the good beta version
git hash 234 [fix apidoc]
git hash 345 for vc1 -- and this is the good release version
git hash 456 [fix apidoc]
```

```
json (simplified)
releaseA {name:releaseA
          statut:released
          milestone[orabettername] {
          123:{datas:beta1,t:beta,p:1},456:{datas:vc1,t:vc,p:2}
          }}
```


I'm not very convinced yet on keeping branding into codebase. Because for me it's only the git hash that make the version. 
Dream but not too far from reality:
I imagine a future build system that use git within ant task (there are still mercurial related task in the antsrc folder, maybe having for git is not big deal) and builnum to be git hash (not jenkins buildnumber).
I imagine a json with only branding for "milestone". 
I imagine the source generating artefacts task to add at root a file release.properties containing (scmhash=,scmbranch=).

User with git
Cloning releaseA
1. try to build,  
2.   git say hash 456 branch releaseA, 
3.   get json info for releaseA hash456 -> no hash info, use releaseA-dev branding

Cloning hash 345
1. try to build,  
2.   git say hash 345 branch releaseA, 
3.   get json info for releaseA hash456 ->info found, 
4.   use releaseA branding (as t==vc and statut==released and last p:position in the list of t==vc)

Cloning hash 123
1. try to build,  
2.   git say hash 123 branch releaseA, 
3.   get json info for releaseA hash456 ->info found, 
4.   use releaseA-beta1(datas) branding (as t!=vc)

Cloning on the 234, 456 hash
1.  same as cloning releaseA, user is between milestone, is on releaseA-dev

Cloning master
1.   git say hash 000 branch master,
2.   get json info for master hash 000 -> no info, use master-dev branding or dev directly 

User downloading sources, not cloning (
1.   git not found,fall back to release.properties informations
2.   no release properties fall back to master-dev or dev directly 

User downloading sources zip from apache distribution (with release.properties)
1. try to build
2.   git not found,fall back to release.properties informations
3.   get json info and build accordingly
@mickaelistria surely the obvious answer is javac?!

If standard JDK is the key feature, then how is it different from https://github.com/georgewfraser/java-language-server ?
(Note that I'm really not trying to sound negative, I'm asking those questions to make sure I understand what cases are going to be better covered by this LS than by existing ones)

So, I think this is a good question.

This project is maintaining editor features that support developing in the Java language (and we could ask why, although that is probably out of the scope of this PR). So adding a fairly small layer that exports a subset of these features through the LSP does not feel to be very off. It is simply providing a way for those that prefer a different UI to use Java editor features this project already has. Not that this PR would be quite there.

The NB Java editor has an ability to use JDK's javac for parsing, so it can in some cases support editing of files with Java language features that are newer than the editor itself. And if a new NB feature is added supporting such a new language feature, the LSP server may use it right away. Yes, other server will get that as well, but as long as we maintain the stuff here,  why not allow access to it using the LSP as well? This is niche, of course.

> I think, we are not good yet for reproducible build, buildnumber is an issue, jdk version, ant version, maven version should be taken into account.

Yes, we're a long way from it!  But it seems to be the right direction of travel.  The build number would be top of the priorities in my opinion because of the issues that caused the re-roll of the Maven vote.  Although part of me thinks making impl. and spec. versions the same would be a good change as well.  Where else is build number used?

> I'm not very convinced yet on keeping branding into codebase. Because for me it's only the git hash that make the version.

The second sentence I totally agree with.  You could achieve same with tagged commits of the version information.  Although really that will be suffix (eg. `-beta1`) only - we'll need all other builds off the release branch to be eg. `11.1-dev+buildnumber` or templating things like the update centres won't work.  "Branding" here includes things that will have functional ramifications.  

> I imagine a future build system that use git within ant task ... and builnum to be git hash

Could even parse that directly from `.git/HEAD` ?

> If standard JDK is the key feature, then how is it different from https://github.com/georgewfraser/java-language-server ?

Until recently that project was also using parts of (pre-Apache) NetBeans' - eg. `nb-javac`.  It also appears at present to have a [license issue](https://github.com/georgewfraser/java-language-server/blob/master/src/main/java/org/javacs/ReusableCompiler.java).

Personally I'd prefer there was an LS as part of the OpenJDK tools.  But having it here seems next best step for an LS backed by javac and building on an editing infrastructure that's widely used.

.git/HEAD contains informations that at first I thoug it was enough. But if you git checkout a particular hash it cannot track the branchs, it's unrelated (detached - french LOCALE :/) head and it only get hase. 
only that is working in this case
`git` branch --remote --verbose --no-abbrev --contains | sed -rne 's/^[^\/]*\/([^\ ]+).*$/\1/p'`

I do not understand the update center part sorry.

> .git/HEAD contains informations that at first I thoug it was enough.

Fair enough - didn't look enough in depth.

> I do not understand the update center part sorry.

One of the things set in branding that needs to pick up the version number (if we want to stop committing it directly) is the URL's of the two update centres, as part of the PR you asked about earlier - eg. https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1304/commits/d7b4dada46349798a1869081fe2327dd0c35d6d6

We should make that eg. `https://netbeans.apache.org/nb/plugins/dev/catalog.xml.gz` in master and handle the actual redirect elsewhere, then replace dev with release eg. `https://netbeans.apache.org/nb/plugins/11.1/catalog.xml.gz`

This needs to be set for every build of the release branch and work locally to be useful though - it can't be just on particular hashes.

to make it clear to me
on master -> https://netbeans.apache.org/nb/plugins/dev/catalog.xml.gz
on release111 (any hash inside) ->https://netbeans.apache.org/nb/plugins/11.1/catalog.xml.gz

Release Manager has to put catalog manually ?

I try some basic step. Can work. Just json granularity not good. update center need to be an url in json not a concat in build helper.
https://github.com/ebarboni/netbeans/commit/2cdf94dcb8ed7a245983f0519ef0f8d079707093
@neilcsmith-net is this good too merge now ? Or master still locked?

@ebarboni yes, currently a manual commit, and what's in master is (was?) broken.  Having just a standard `/dev/...` link was my thought on moving the existing master links somewhere we can just handle via redirects same as releases.

Full links works, and possibly better, although I was initially thinking we could replace `/dev/` with `/{version}/` ?
Master was already open, we have two positive reviews, will merge. Thank you.

Thanks for the feedback @matthiasblaesing.  Unfortunately, I cannot make the requested changes as it seems like it is no longer possible to create Amazon Beanstalk server instances in NB11.1 or builds from master? (Only Tomcat, Glassfish and Payara servers can be created)

I'm not sure if this is as accidental bug that has been introduced, or if it is a deliberate decision to remove AWS support?  If the later, this PR could be Closed.

Why would there be a deliberate decision to remove AWS support? :-) If there's a bug, just file an issue, and since you're doing great with your enhancements and fixes, please also consider fixing it.

As I already said: I don't own an AWS account, so you need to tell me a bit more, where you expect what. There was some work in the JavaEE area to support JavaEE8 and this might have disrupted things, but with a recent local build, I have the "Cloud" entry in the services tab. Please check if the JavaEE plugins are all activated.

With a fresh install of NB11.1 and enabling all Java + JavaEE features, where the Amazon Beanstalk entry is missing is:

New Project -> Java with Maven -> Java Web -> Server & Settings -> JavaEE7 -> Add

Amazon Beanstalk should be in the list of Server types to add to the Project, but isn't anymore (Only Tomcat, Glassfish & Payara).  

I remember seeing something on the NB Mailing list about duplicate entries in this dialog after Payara was merged in, so suspect it may be related to this (rather than JavaEE8), but without tracing the related commits/PRs and going through the code I can't be certain at this point.

I will have a look myself if I get time.

I think you mean PR #1347, indeed that PR looks as if it touched relevant code. @jGauravGupta could you please have a look at this PR. Long story short: AWS entries are expected to be present in the list of Java EE servers but are not anymore.

What do you think about combining the efforts on building great Kotlin support by focusing on improving the [Kotlin language server](https://github.com/fwcd/KotlinLanguageServer)?

An LSP client for NetBeans seems to have been merged some time ago (#629) and having a well-maintained language server would benefit other editors/IDEs too.

> What I'm wondering is, why does this pull request pass the CI test if it's disapproved of by the rat job because of missing licenses?

The rat check in the CI run does not check the git repository, but the released source zip. As the language files are not part of the build, they don't cause a build failure.
Sure @matthiasblaesing, soon I will have look on this issue.
Thank you, @jGauravGupta !!
We probably do not need customizations in `webcommon/libs.nashorn/build.xml` either, since JS parser lib can be part of the regular build (?)

@JaroslavTulach Maybe, `php.editor` also needs the fix? 
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/39e97b900a8d604f3968e07605ee0d7709f37977/php/php.editor/nbproject/project.properties#L81-L82
This is great, no more need for the user to install the parser themselves.

Yes, still issues after changing the LaF w/o restarting it. It only reloads some parts but not the whole IDE. Still buggy with that option. I know that restart is needed for NetBeans but there need a rethink, because other IDEs can handle it too.

Anyway, will create a new ticket for that. Thx for the help :)
@Chris2011 yes, likely still requires something akin to the first hack in the post I linked - fully nuking the UIDefaults table?

Hi @peedeeboy,

I also don't have AWS account. May you review and test the PR feature: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1412

Thank you - a build worked and starting with a clean userdir, all JS features were directly accessible (nice!). I had a first look at the sources and this is what I noticed:

**Build from source fails**

mx still feels alien to me and I failed to build graal.js from source:
- cloned https://github.com/graalvm/mx.git
- checked out 5.229.5
- added path to mx checkout to path
- cloned https://github.com/JaroslavTulach/graaljs.git
- changed into graaljs/graal-js and ran `mx build --project GRAAL_JS_PARSER` 
```
matthias@athena:~/src/graaljs/graal-js$ mx build --project GRAAL_JS_PARSER
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/matthias/src/mx/mx.py", line 19726, in <module>
    main()
  File "/home/matthias/src/mx/mx.py", line 19613, in main
    primary = _discover_suites(primarySuiteMxDir, load=should_load_suites)
  File "/home/matthias/src/mx/mx.py", line 3364, in _discover_suites
    _register_visit(primary)
  File "/home/matthias/src/mx/mx.py", line 3362, in _register_visit
    s._load()
  File "/home/matthias/src/mx/mx.py", line 1506, in _load
    self._load_extensions()
  File "/home/matthias/src/mx/mx.py", line 1931, in _load_extensions
    mod = __import__(extensionsName)
  File "/home/matthias/src/graaljs/graal-js/mx.graal-js/mx_graal_js.py", line 338, in <module>
    build_args=['--language:js']
TypeError: __init__() takes at least 6 arguments (5 given)
matthias@athena:~/src/graaljs/graal-js$ 
```
Am I missing something?

**License information**

A _quick_ check of the licenses (aka `grep -lr "GNU General " *`) gave me:

GPL license header:
graal-js/mx.graal-js/mx_graal_js.py
graal-js/mx.graal-js/mx_graal_js_benchmark.py
graal-js/src/com.oracle.js.parser/src/com/oracle/js/parser/package-info.java
graal-js/src/com.oracle.js.parser/src/com/oracle/js/parser/resources/Messages.properties

GPL license file:
graal-js/mx.graal-js/LICENSE

GPL+UPL header, without indication that the file is dual licensed:
graal-js/src/com.oracle.truffle.js.runtime/src/com/oracle/truffle/js/runtime/builtins/JSURLEncoder.java
graal-js/src/com.oracle.truffle.js.runtime/src/com/oracle/truffle/js/runtime/builtins/JSURLDecoder.java

GPL+UPL+BSD license:
graal-js/src/com.oracle.truffle.js.runtime.doubleconv/src/com/oracle/truffle/js/runtime/doubleconv/DiyFp.java
graal-js/src/com.oracle.truffle.js.runtime.doubleconv/src/com/oracle/truffle/js/runtime/doubleconv/DoubleConversion.java

There are other licenses on graal-nodejs, I hope, that no code outside graal-js is used for graal-js.

Hi @jGauravGupta !  Thanks for looking into this.

Whilst there is now a "Amazon Beanstalk" option in the Add Server wizard when creating a new project, it seems to be opening `org.netbeans.modules.cloud.amazon.ui.AmazonWizardComponent` which creates a new node under Services -> Cloud.

This doesn't create a new instance under Services -> Server, so it is still not possible to create the Project.

I believe that the New Server wizard used to open `org.netbeans.modules.cloud.amazon.ui.serverplugin.AmazonJ2EEServerWizardComponent` when "Amazon Beanstalk" was selected, which does create a node under Services -> Server.

So the workflow to set up AWS used to be to go to Services -> Cloud -> Add Instance and create the AWS instance including Secret Key etc.

Then Project ->New Project -> Java Web and in the Add Server dialog choose "Amazon Beanstalk" and create a Server that referenced that cloud instance

(It wasn't a great workflow to start with!).  Hope that makes sense?  I can provide some screenshots if needed :)

Thanks for the detailed review, @matthiasblaesing. The `TypeError: __init__() takes at least 6 arguments (5 given)` problem has something to do with old/new version of `mx`. I have seen it as well before (but not when writing the above steps). The workaround was:
```diff
graal-js$ git diff
diff --git a/graal-js/mx.graal-js/mx_graal_js.py b/graal-js/mx.graal-js/mx_graal_js.py
index bb59b035d7..ae60755801 100644
--- a/graal-js/mx.graal-js/mx_graal_js.py
+++ b/graal-js/mx.graal-js/mx_graal_js.py
@@ -331,12 +331,6 @@ mx_sdk.register_graalvm_component(mx_sdk.GraalVmLanguage(
         'graal-js:ICU4J-DIST'
     ],
     launcher_configs=[
-        mx_sdk.LanguageLauncherConfig(
-            destination='bin/<exe:js>',
-            jar_distributions=['graal-js:GRAALJS_LAUNCHER'],
-            main_class='com.oracle.truffle.js.shell.JSLauncher',
-            build_args=['--language:js']
-        )
     ],
     boot_jars=['graal-js:GRAALJS_SCRIPTENGINE']
 ))
``` 

Thanks for the license check. Yes, the `graal-js/src/com.oracle.js.parser/src/com/oracle/js/parser/package-info.java` and `graal-js/src/com.oracle.js.parser/src/com/oracle/js/parser/resources/Messages.properties` are an oversight. It has just been fixed in [cdbd80a95](https://github.com/JaroslavTulach/graaljs/commit/cdbd80a9506d316f2d65cfb388968a2c326ec6d9). The other files are unrelated and I'd rather leave them without any modification. They aren't used in the parser anyway. When I run:
```
graaljs/graal-js$ mx clean
graaljs/graal-js$ mx -v build --project GRAAL_JS_PARSER
javac -g -d mxbuild/src/com.oracle.js.parser/bin -classpath  
-parameters -proc:none -target 1.8 -source 1.8 
@mxbuild/src/com.oracle.js.parser/javafilelist.txt 
-Xlint:none -XDignore.symbol.file -encoding UTF-8 -Xmaxerrs 10000
```
e.g. it should be enough to run just the `javac` and then package the source and resource files somehow:
```
$ /jdk1.8.0/bin/javac -g -d mxbuild/src/com.oracle.js.parser/bin 
-classpath  -parameters -proc:none -target 1.8 -source 1.8 
@mxbuild/src/com.oracle.js.parser/javafilelist.txt 
-Xlint:none -XDignore.symbol.file -encoding UTF-8 -Xmaxerrs 10000
```
The `javafilelist.txt` contains only files under the `src/com.oracle.js.parser/src` directory, so licenses of other files shall not matter.

Also you can test your changes, just clone the repo, go into the netbeans_snap or netbeans-dev_snap directory and execute snapcraft to build that snap. when it is ready you can test it with:
snap install netbeans....snap --dangerous --classic
Also the dev version is built and uploaded on every Thursday so your changes would be there for test for "broader" audiance: snap install netbeans-dev --channel edge --classic

> I'd remove the version number from the end.

@lkishalmi but it won't work in that case! Looks like we might need to reconsider how the following code works, or find a way to template along with other uses of the version numbers in the build?

@tmysik Fixed. Thank you!

A big chunk of the problem here is how many fingers there are in the resolution pie:

 * Monitor firmware may or may not be reporting a broken value to the kernel
 * User may or may not [have overridden it](https://www.96boards.org/documentation/consumer/dragonboard/dragonboard410c/guides/force-display-res.md.html)
 * X configuration may or may not try to adjust it further
 * Different JDKs do different things to try and fix it

The alternative is, on first start, run a UI that modifies the netbeans.conf - I've actually got that written, before I said to myself "This is insane, you should be able to figure it out on startup" - one that simply shows a bunch of examples for font size, and then for LCD settings, and says "which one looks better?" and lets the user pick.

I'll throw that up on Github and link it here.  It's not as nice as solving the problem automagically, but it's better than the IDE looking like complete crap for a new user.

I'm sure that this is actually required, Gradle Tooling API with Gradle Daemon can't auto add jvmargs from gradle.properties file. only run gradle command can add jvmargs from gradle.properties. If you have a better way to limit memory of gradle daemon in netbeans, please let me know.

> What do you think about combining the efforts on building great Kotlin support by focusing on improving the [Kotlin language server](https://github.com/fwcd/KotlinLanguageServer)?
> 
> An LSP client for NetBeans seems to have been merged some time ago (#629) and having a well-maintained language server would benefit other editors/IDEs too.

I think using the LSP server may be a viable alternative, but those who will decide to work on the support for Kotlin in NetBeans will need to decide between two alternatives:
-using the LSP server, which is easier to integrate (the biggest issue will probably be categorizing licenses and finding places from where NB can download the binaries - the NetBeans build likes to download stuff from Maven central, but my understanding is that most of the binaries required here are not in central), the con being that there are limits in how well such integration may work without special tweaks in the IDE. (Like having a Java class referring to a Kotlin class, or support for features that are not supported by the LSP.)

-have a plugin directly in the IDE, where there are no limits on the integration with other features; the obvious con being this is much more work.
Ok. Go ahead and do the requested changes. Thank you for your contribution!

@jmborer Thank you for your reply.
> Question (stupid one) how can I test the code myself?

#### How to build
See https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/README.md

#### How to apply this patch
Maybe, there are some ways, I suppose. 
One of the simplest ways:
```sh
git clone git@github.com:apache/netbeans.git
# or git clone https://github.com/apache/netbeans.git
cd netbeans
git checkout -b pr1402
curl -L https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1402.patch | git am
```
BTW, you are on vacation. So, when are you going to do it?
